explanation:
1) charsequalcaseless
- Reason: It is called from inside the loop body. MISRA states that the behaviour of functions called within a loop body is part of the loop body behaviour. To decide if the loop (here a while) would violate the spirit of the MISRA for‑loop well‑formedness rule (i.e. modify loop control objects or have persistent side effects) we must know whether charsequalcaseless has any side effects: does it modify any global or static objects, does it modify memory reachable from its arguments, or does it depend on/modify any objects that participate in loop control (for example str1, str2, or any globals used as loop counters/flags). Provide the full implementation or prototype and any globals/static data it accesses.

2) isasciiupper
- Reason: charsequalcaseless calls isasciiupper. Its implementation or macro expansion may have side effects or depend on global/state (or be a macro referencing other objects). To be sure charsequalcaseless is free of side effects, the definition of isasciiupper must be inspected (function or macro). Provide its definition or header.

Note: If charsequalcaseless references any additional functions or global variables, those symbols (and their definitions) must also be supplied, because any function or global that can be modified or that influences control flow from within the loop body is relevant under the MISRA rule.
